docs.lead_paragraph: The end of life has become an alien experience for those of us living in countries where most people spend their final days in institutional settings. As a result, conversing with people fast approaching the end of life is foreign for many people, who may be reluctant to visit dying friends or relatives because they do not know what to say or do. There is no better time to learn than now, when more and more people are dying of protracted illnesses in hospitals, nursing homes, hospices and, increasingly, at home with hospice care. While physicians may do an excellent job treating potentially curable illnesses, after modern medicine has no further treatment to offer, they often become tongue-tied and may even abandon their patients, leaving the task of emotional support to friends and family.

headline.main: Art and Grace, When It's Time to Say Goodbye

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column lends advice on dealing with person who is dying; book I Don't Know What to Say by Dr Robert Buckman, University of Toronto medical oncologist, is discussed and specific ways to ease feeling of isolation for patient detailed; article holds that being accessible, supportive and interested without giving unwanted advice or breeding conflict is extremely helpful to individuals wanting closure before death; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The end of life has become an alien experience for those of us living in countries where most people spend their final days in institutional settings. As a result, conversing with people fast approaching the end of life is foreign for many people,...

keywords.value: I DON'T KNOW WHAT TO SAY (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: It wasn't always obvious that the Vacanti boys Jay, Chuck, Marty and Frank -- were destined to become doctor-scientists, much less that they would come to dominate the esoteric field of tissue engineering. Their specialty involves growing human spare parts like cartilage, bone, blood vessels and, perhaps some day, whole livers, hearts and kidneys in the laboratory.

headline.main: From Old Cars to Cartilage, Brothers Like to Tinker
headline.kicker: SCIENTISTS AT WORK -- JOSEPH, CHARLES, MARTIN AND FRANCIS VACANTI

docs.abstract: Four Vacanti brothers, Charles, Martin, Francis and Joseph, are all research physicans at hospitals in Boston (Mass) and dominate field of tissue engineering; family background growing up in Omaha (Neb) is discussed as springboard to current collaborative efforts in medical science; each man's path and accomplishments discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A part of the brain involved in emotion is much smaller in both teenagers and adults who have bipolar disorder, a recent study has found, a discovery that may help doctors make an earlier diagnosis of the disease. The researchers, who reported their findings in the current issue of The Archives of General Psychiatry, looked at the amygdala, a small part of the brain in the front temporal lobe.

headline.main: Scanning a Brain for Bipolar Root

docs.abstract: Yale University Dr Hilary P Blumberg leads research into bipolar disorder recently published in Archives of General Psychiatry; study finds smaller amygdala, emotional center of brain, is common in both children and adults with bipolar disorder; holds that information could be valuable tool in early diagnosis of illness (S)
docs.snippet: A part of the brain involved in emotion is much smaller in both teenagers and adults who have bipolar disorder, a recent study has found, a discovery that may help doctors make an earlier diagnosis of the disease.    The researchers, who reported...

docs.lead_paragraph: The year was 1958, I was 16 and my mother was lying in a hospital bed connected to all sorts of tubes and was dying of cancer. As her life slipped away, a nurse slapped an oxygen mask on her face and asked me to hold it. There was no chance for either of us to say goodbye or ''I love you.'' I carry this medicalized memory of my mother's death with me to this day. I am hardly alone. Cicely Saunders, the founder of the first modern hospice, said, ''How people die remains in the memories of those who live on.''

headline.main: Facing Up to the Inevitable, in Search of a Good Death

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody article discusses caring for dying patients and their families; Rose Virani, City of Hope National Medical Center research specialist, and writer Dalia Sofer note in article appearing in American Journal of Nursing that many deaths are made more chaotic by poor communication and over- or under-treating patients; American Geriatrics Society lists nine important factors for quality care at life's end; factors address care before and after death for patient and family; Elizabeth Ford Pitorak, Hospice Institute of Hospice of the Western Reserve (Cleveland, Ohio) director, describes process of active dying or total body failure and outlines specific ways to help patient through process; role of doctors in caring for patients approaching death discussed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study over 15 years has found that people approaching middle age were more likely to have high blood pressure and diabetes if they did poorly on treadmill tests as young adults, ages 18 to 30. The findings suggest that it is important to lay the groundwork for cardiovascular health early.

headline.main: Dividends for the Young and Fit

docs.abstract: Northwestern University Dr Mercedes R Carnethon publishes results of study on early fitness and effect on future problems with high blood pressure and diabetes in Journal of American Medical Assn; findings show that individuals testing at low fitness levels at ages 15 to 30 are three to six times as likely as more fit contemporaries to have diabetes or high blood pressure 15 years later; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A study over 15 years has found that people approaching middle age were more likely to have high blood pressure and diabetes if they did poorly on treadmill tests as young adults, ages 18 to 30.     The findings suggest that it is important to lay...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women with recurrent symptomatic yeast infections often believe that their sexual partners may be to blame for reinfecting them. But a new study finds that outbreaks in women are not related to infections in their partners. The idea was that yeast infections, recurrent problems for about 40 percent of women, tended to be passed to their partners, who then passed it back after the symptoms had cleared up.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researcher Dr Barbara D Reed leads study on recurrent, symptomatic yeast infections; study, published in Journal of Women's Health, shows women do not become reinfected by sexual partner; some specific sexual practices are linked to recurrent yeast infections; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Women with recurrent symptomatic yeast infections often believe that their sexual partners may be to blame for reinfecting them. But a new study finds that outbreaks in women are not related to infections in their partners.    The idea was that yeast...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of recent food-borne hepatitis A outbreaks, scientists and medical experts are urging the federal government to intensify its efforts to quash the disease. Now more than ever, some argue, there is a need for widespread vaccination against hepatitis A.

headline.main: Experts Seek New Effort To Control Hepatitis A

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and American Academy of Pediatrics have recommended childhood vaccination in 11 Western states for food-borne hepatitis A since 1999; article contends that recent outbreaks involving contaminated produce shipped from areas rife with hepatitis will likely continue and recognizes that support for universal vaccination to thwart spread is gaining ground; hepatitis A is described (S)
docs.snippet: In the wake of recent food-borne hepatitis A outbreaks, scientists and medical experts are urging the federal government to intensify its efforts to quash the disease.    Now more than ever, some argue, there is a need for widespread vaccination...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ah, those were the days. At least that's what the nostalgic among us feel. And those hard-nosed realists who are immune to its siren call dismiss it -- wrongly, of course -- as cheap sentiment. I remember during a particularly grueling time of medical internship joking with a colleague that one day we would look back on that year with fondness. Clearly, he thought I must be crazy. But two years later, he was bragging to me about our having lived through the days of the giants, his bittersweet and almost nostalgic label of rough days gone by.
docs.abstract: Human recall, or effect of nostalgia, is assessed through studies of brain function; article holds that memory from early childhood is limited because hippocampus, memory cicuit, is not yet developed in child's brain and only memories involving traumatic events, which are processed by amygdala, are retained; effects of adrenaline on memory discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A small group of molecules has been shown to inhibit a deadly toxin associated with inhalational anthrax, a discovery that could lead to new ways of treating the disease, researchers said on Monday. Scientists at Harvard Medical School and Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center here said the finding might help in the development of a drug that when combined with antibiotics, could treat inhalational anthrax when antibiotics alone were no longer effective.

headline.main: Finding May Help Fight Anthrax Toxin, Scientists Say

docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School and Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center report that they have indentified small group of molecules that inhibit deadly toxin associated with inhalational anthrax; study, led by Dr Lewis C Cantley and published in journal Nature Structural & Molecular Biology, suggests that therapeutic combination of anitbiotics and protease inhibitors could be effective in treating those infected with air-borne anthrax and reduce need for widespread vaccination (M)
docs.snippet: A small group of molecules has been shown to inhibit a deadly toxin associated with inhalational anthrax, a discovery that could lead to new ways of treating the disease, researchers said on Monday.    Scientists at Harvard Medical School and Beth...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who have lupus, an autoimmune disease, are at higher risk for heart disease, even if they do not have the customary warning signs like high blood pressure or high cholesterol, researchers have found. The findings have implications not just for the treatment of lupus but for understanding what causes plaque to build up along the walls of the coronary arteries, bringing on atherosclerosis.

headline.main: Tricky Lupus Goes for the Heart

docs.abstract: Dr Mary J Roman, Weill Medical College of Cornell University researcher writing in New England Journal of Medicine, notes that Lupus patients are 140 percent more likely to have atherosclerosis than non-Lupus individuals tested; study holds that inflammatory nature of disease may cause atherosclerosis; drawing (S)
